FacilityName: Henningsen Cold Storage Co. Grand Forks, ND

9. Hot Work Permits: A Hot Work Permit program is in place at this facility which requires a Hot Work
Permit to be initiated prior to working on or near the process. Specific requirements are outlined in the permit that are to be followed before, during and after the completion of the hot work

10. Management of Change (MOC): A MOC system is implemented. MOCs are planned, tracked, and reviewed using the Management of Change policies and procedures, as well as utilizing the required documentation and forms.

11. Incident Investigation: All incidents and near-misses are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an incident investigation form. Deficiencies are noted in the de-briefing and are addressed in a timely manner.

12. Emergency Planning and Response: The facility does not respond to ammonia releases, therefore they do not have an Emergency Response Plan.

13. Compliance Audits: Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that all elements within the scope of PSM and RMP are adhered to.

14. Five-Year Accident History: No ammonia related incidents have occurred at this facility in the past five years. Accidents are reported immediately.

15. Description of plans to improve safety: Continued safety education is paramount to HCS core values.
Engineers are required to attend ammonia safety refresher training annually. If the facility changes or expands, Management will ensure that all equipment will be designed, rated, constructed and installed for ammonia refrigeration system usage using good engineering practices and applicable codes. All elements within PSM and RMP will be addressed in a timely fashion and all employees whose jobs are affected by any change will be properly trained.

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM-ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Henningsen Cold Storage Co. (HCS) Grand Forks, North Dakota facility is a public refrigerated warehouse. The facility contains freezer warehouse spaces which are used to store frozen perishable products. The facility has nine truck loading and unloading stations and five railcar stations used for shipping and receiving of customer owned product. Warehouse storage spaces at the facility are maintained at a temperature of 0Â°f or below. In order to maintain desired temperatures, a mechanical refrigeration system utilizing anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant is employed. The refrigeration system is a closed loop system; the ammonia is not mixed with any other chemical or used in any other process.

FACILITY CONSTRUCTION: The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with various Mechanical and Building Codes in effect at the time of construction. These codes and guidelines outline requirements for the safe construction and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.

SAFETY FEATURES: The ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Examples include but are not limited to pressure relief valves, remotely controlled solenoids and stop valves, monitored ammonia detection system, automatic engine room ventilation systems, computerized refrigeration monitoring and control system with alarm and failure notification via auto-dialer, as well as trained and experienced operators. Much of the safety associated with the system is also inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with the OSHA PSM (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119) and EPA's RMP (Risk Management Program, 40 CFR Part 68) standards.

MANAGEMENT COMMITMENT TO SAFETY: Management takes safety very seriously and mandates that the facility maintain a safe working environment for employees, visitors, neighbors, and

o in an emergency situation. 
8. Hot Work Permit Procedures are followed, and all persons affected by the hot work are made aware of potential hazards.
9. Compliance Audits are performed regularly; recommendations from the audits are assigned to proper personnel, and are addressed in a timely manner. 
10. Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are filled out when required, reviewed prior to conducting the change on the system and completed prior to placing ammonia into the affected portion of the system. 
11. All employees are trained on all elements of the Emergency Action Plan and that the plan is reviewed and certified annually.
12. Mechanical Integrity Inspections and tests are performed to ensure that the ammonia equipment is operating safely, and is in acceptable condition to continue operating. All deficiencies are noted and addressed in a timely manner. 
13. Incident Investigations are performed on accidental ammonia releases as well as near-misses, and any resulting recommendations are assigned and addressed in a timely manner. Investigation results are utilized to improve steps to taken when using the emergency action plan.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: There have been no reportable ammonia related accidents, incidents or releases at the facility during the past five years.

EMERGENCY ACTION PROGRAM: The facility has established an Emergency Action Plan. The Plan explains what actions employees, contractor employees, and visitors are to take in the event of an emergency involving ammonia, fire, or other hazard.
The Emergency Action Plan states that all employees shall:
1. Notify a supervisor or main office personnel of the emergency, so they can initiate facility evacuation by activating the public announcement (PA) system.
2. Notify the appropriate emergency responders.
3. Notify on-site contractors or visitors to evacuate the building.
4. Participate and assist in a safe and orderly evacuation.
5. Gather and remain at the designated assembly

area(s) for a head count.

In the event of an ammonia release, employees are instructed to follow the steps as noted above.
Maintenance employees that have been properly trained on the usage of the hand-held ammonia detector may use it, along with the proper PPE, and the buddy system in an attempt to locate the ammonia leak. In the event that readings on the detector reach the IDLH level for ammonia of 300 parts per million employees are instructed to re-evacuate immediately to the designated assembly area, report all findings to the incident commander, supervisor or management and await further instruction.
The Emergency Action Plan is reviewed and updated annually.

PREVENTION PROGRAM 3:
1. Employee Participation: Employees such as the Chief Engineer, Assistant Engineer, Engineering Supervisors and Management are actively involved in the development and implementation of PSM and RMP programs. Employees aid in gathering Process Safety Information, development and implementation of Operating Procedures, are members of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), aiding in the completion of recommendations from both PHA and Compliance Audits, and the screening process for hiring Contractors.

2. Process Safety Information: Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs) have been developed showing all piping and major components of the ammonia refrigeration system. Valves and other components have been assigned unique identifiers. Information has been gathered to enable employees to identify and understand the potential hazards of the process. The Process Safety Information also includes a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia, an ammonia inventory, materials of construction description, electrical classification document, pressure relief valve system design calculations, engine room ventilation design calculations, as well as other required documentation. All of this documentation is retained in the PSI Library. All components of the refrigeration system are d

products at all times. Employees are trained on all safety hazards relative to their duties and tasks and are made aware of all regulatory required safety programs. A Safety Committee has been established at the facility, and is made up of hourly employees, supervisors and/or management personnel. The primary responsibility of the Safety Committee is to meet, discuss and address safety issues. The Committee also may conduct safety inspections of the facility at various times to look for potentially unsafe conditions or procedures that may exist. 
Management is committed to providing the necessary resources to ensure that all elements of safety regulations are adhered to.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM: A Management System has been developed and implemented to ensure that each element within PSM and RMP regulations is properly addressed. Each person outlined in the Â¿ResponsibilitiesÂ¿ section of the Management System is assigned various tasks and/or components of the regulations and is expected to aid in the development and implementation of the program as a whole. The group works as a team to make certain that all requirements are met, and to ensure that: 
1. Employees participate in the development and implementation of the programs.
2. Employees aid in gathering Process Safety Information.
3. Standard Operating Procedures pertaining to the refrigeration system are developed, implemented, reviewed and recertified annually. 
4. Safe Work Practices are developed and followed.
5. Proper personnel serve as members of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team and that all recommendations from the PHA are addressed in a timely manner. 
6. All potentially affected employees are trained to the awareness level, and those whose jobs include working on or near the refrigeration system are appropriately trained. 
7. Contractors are qualified to work on or near the refrigeration system, and are informed about potential health and safety risks associated with the system, as well as what to d

esigned maintained and operated utilizing good engineering practices.

3. Process Hazard Analysis: A formal study of the ammonia refrigeration system with Management, Safety, and Maintenance personnel was conducted using the Â¿what-ifÂ¿ method to evaluate the potential hazards of the system. A recommendation summary is used to track completion of all recommendations.

4. Operating Procedures: Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) have been developed and implemented to ensure safe operation of the refrigeration system. SOPs are used when training and are annually reviewed and recertified by the Chief Engineer.

5. Training: All ammonia refrigeration maintenance employees, Chief Engineers and Assistant Engineers are trained on all aspects of the ammonia system. Each Engineer is required to attend various types of training relative to the ammonia system and/or their respective duties and tasks. Employees are also encouraged to attend any other training that may be useful to them during their day to day operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.

6. Contractors: Contractors are screened and evaluated prior to performing work-on or near the ammonia refrigeration system. Contractors are trained on the safety and hazards of the system and are required to meet with the Chief Engineer prior to working on the system. A training session is held to ensure that all aspects of safety have been addressed. Documentation of training is retained.

7. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR): A PSSR includes policy and procedures as well as a checklist to ensure that all documents relating to the PSSR are collected, reviewed and retained. Each Engineer is trained on the PSSR.

8. Mechanical Integrity: A Mechanical Integrity policy and procedures have been implemented at this facility. Mechanical Integrity Inspections are performed annually. Engineers conduct daily walk-through inspections, maintain system log sheets, generate preventative maintenance work orders, and conduct period
